body.title: EPPO simple paragraph
body.p: An EPPO simple paragraph comprises text, annotations, links, or other inline components to form a textual building block of a composition. Except in titles or in other elements that accept only simple text, the paragraph element, p, is needed wherever text is needed, including the following:

section.title: Structure
section.p:
Whereas most elements accept only other elements or only text, a paragraph element,

, may contain a mixture of text and inline elements. We group inline elements in the following categories, according to the role they play:

li.p: Decorated-text elements affect how text is displayed.
Subject-annotation elements identify terms that the SPFE build system will soft link to related topics.
Link elements connect to specific resources through a URI or web address.
Resource elements reference other elements through an identifier.
String elements allow strings to be identified so they can be reused.

caption.p: Each component is optional and may appear any number of times, as indicated by the 0+ annotations.

section.codeblock: Text may need to be displayed in bold face or italics in many situations. Just remember that these are display properties only; they carry no meaning other than to the human eye. Though the code element may appear similar to the bold element, it's best to reserve it for text that is code, such as the XML <bold> and <quote> tags. section.title: Subject annotation
section.p: The SPFE build system will link subject-annotated terms to topics that list those terms in their index, which is a component in each topic's header. The build system creates an index with a list of topics for each subject-annotation term. The lists are organized by subject type identified by the subject-annotation tag.
Figure 4 lists the subject-annotation tags that EPPO-simple provides.

section.title: Links
section.p: Links to external resources or websites are created with either the link-external or url element. The former works like the HTML <a> element; it wraps a text string with a tag with an href attribute, which specifies a URI. The <url> tag, on the other hand, simply wraps a web address.
